title: Ghostcrawler and Meddler misunderstand what makes pro-play enjoyable.
body:
Pro-play used to put you on edge because the game was centered around playing smart and strategic. Each team had the potential to play it smarter than their opponents and make a comeback.

Now I turn off games sub ~10 minutes because the outcome is basically decided by then, there really is no point in watching beyond that. Games are no longer strategic battles, it's whoever shoots first. It's basically turned into CS:GO.

Ghostcrawler, Meddler, you're misinterpreting the game, it's a strategy MOBA, not a twitch shooter.

Basically, Korean games ending quickly has nothing to do with Riot. Riot can't please the Koreans because the Koreans don't give a fuck whether Riot is lengthening or shortening the game duration. Due to their circumstances, Koreans will always end games quicker regardless. It doesn't favor Koreans because it doesn't change anything in Korea.

People just see a similarity and they immediately make a connection, ignoring all common sense.  These ignorant people love shutting down their brains and creating false narratives of how the Koreans are so happy with the state of the game and how Riot wants to continue pleasing them. Which is absolute bull shit.

Finally attributing lower quality games to Korea is being rude to a nation that's many steps ahead in terms of e-culture. Crowds grouping up to watch games in studios? (like NA LCS) Yeah those existed in Korea before I was even born. 

An FPS game called "Sudden Attack" used to be the most popular FPS game in Korea (CS coming in second) before Overwatch. So to match the release of Overwatch, Nexon released "Sudden Attack 2"- it was highly anticipated to take back it's rightful place as the #1 FPS game in Korea. Guess what? Koreans literally killed the game after its release because of 1. Lack of Quality 2. Pay-to-win Items in store 3. Over-sexual death poses 4. Inaccurate weapons. Due to the hate and boycotting, Nexon had to close the game. This is just one example of how aggressive Koreans are when it comes to judging the quality of a game. 

Which is why comments that imply Koreans must like League rn when it's at a shit state is so far from the truth. "But muh there are so many Koreans still playing League while people are quitting here" That's because Korea has a more loyal playerbase when it comes to League and games like Fortnite/Realm Royal (that's "stealing" a lot of players) don't have a notable following in Korea. Like Starcraft1, League managed to ascend past other games and become a defining part of Korean culture. It's watchable in your home Television, the e-communities embrace the game, and Faker is arguably more popular than the Korean President. You think a ~~game~~ national sport like that can simply "die" because of fortnite and god-tier shitty balancing? lmao it will take more than that.

I'm still tired but I'll explain before I go to bed. Mind you, this will be a sea of spelling, and grammatical errors. 
(It's indirectly mentioned in the thread linked in my previous comment) PC Bangs are popular because Koreans (especially students) are very much restricted and under the authority of their parents at home. Meaning, in Korea if your mom calls you for dinner during a ranked match, you are going to lose that LP real quick. 

Jokes aside, it's similar to how love hotels in Japan exist for couples wanting to have sex and how it's pretty awkward to do it at home due to close family structures (always someone at home). 
And of course, you will see clueless outsiders calling it a place for prostitutes when prostitution is fucking banned in Japan.  
Like people need to start understanding that it can be very rude misinterpreting and boldly expanding on a small piece of information you think you know about a culture when you don't. 

Anyways, here are the details of a PC bang: 

PC bangs are usually quite dark inside. Imagine a movie theater where everyone breaks the rules and turns on their phones. The bright lights in a PC bang would be the monitors which can be as big as 32 inches. 24 and 27 is more common I think. And it's bright enough so you wouldn't trip or anything. 

There is usually a counter near the entrance where a dude (or a hot girl in the PC bang I go to- lucky me) accepts payment. If you are a guest, it's around a dollar or a dollar and a half per hour. If you get a membership (which might cost you at first) costs will be cheaper (cheaper eventually considering if it was a paid membership) 
It feels cheap at first but time goes so fast when playing games lol

Near the counter is pretty bright and there are refreshments of all sorts nearby. Practically a small convenience store is in there but with only things that are edible and purchasable game currency cards for whatever game. You can also order food from outside (Pizza, etc). 

The temperature is always cool because there are huge fans and ACs running 24/7. 

A normal PC bang could probably fit around 80-100 people. Larger ones can fit more. Smaller ones- less. 
After walking pass a bunch of rows of computers placed in cubical areas (for personal space), you'll probably see a smoking room or bathroom at the back end of the room. 

The equipment is lit (gaming chair, headset, keyboard, mouse etc). The computers are really fast and I haven't experienced any lag of any sort so far. 
LED lights of different colors can come from the equipment, the ceiling, or the floor. 

If you are under 18 or 19 (I can't remember), you can't stay in a PC Bang after 9PM. A few PC bangs don't allow people from a certain age group as well. 

Understand that Koreans are really picky when it comes to cleanliness. I've lived in Europe, Africa, America and Korea- and I can tell you it's pretty ridiculous how far these Koreans can go. I mean in most houses you don't even wear shoes inside. 

So a PC bang that's not clean, smells like sweat or food, has poor/cheap equipment, and or bad management (keeping noise down) will always go out of business. Always. It's because no matter where one lives in the city, there is at least 5 competing PC bangs from a 3-8 minutes walk distance. 

I have a friend who's family is pretty rich (owns hotels and what not). They also own high tier private PC Bang and it has glass tiles with water underneath. 99.99% of PC bangs aren't like that. 

It's 3AM here. Goodnight.

This is not how the game has ever been.  You pick an early game champ for a strategic advantage early.  You are EXPECTED to be ahead with a lane bully.  The impetus is now on you to do something with the advantage you should have.  Time is against you.  That's the point.  Why do they feel entitled to win?  Because they made a strategic decision to pick a scaling teamfight comp.  

You're basically saying that if you pick a lane bully champ against a scaling teamfighter and you win lane (Which should be easy to do, and is EXPECTED for that to happen) you should just automatically win the game.  

The reward for being ahead early isn't that you just get to win and I don't understand why people think that. It's that you get first tower, vision control over objectives, probably item leads, ability to roam, your job is to take those advantages and press them to a win.  Just like it's up to the scaling comp to play smart, play safe, don't get picked, and play defensively until you're stronger.  

If you pick lane bullies and go up two towers and a few kills and once the map opens up you get picked and play like a bunch of apes, you should not win despite the fact that you are ahead.  Your champ picks gave you advantages, you failed to do anything with it.  You shouldn't be rewarded for that.  If you got ahead with an early game comp and turned it into a bunch of picks cause they have no vision, turned it into a baron, and played aggressively with your advantage, THEN you deserve to win.

If you picked a scaling comp and took stupid fights in lane and fed, you should probably end up losing.  If you played smart, kept up in farm, waited for jung pressure, didn't get picked, played smart around vision, and didn't give the early-mid game comp an opportunity to press their advantage, you deserve to win.
